title: Inflation Pushing Real Interest Rates Into Negative Territory; Rising Prices Wearing Down U.S. Workers
text:
Top News

Inflation Pushes U.S. Real Interest Rates More Into Negative Territory

In economic models, it is the inflation-adjusted—or "real"—interest rate that matters most, because inflation reduces the value of future repayments. The real rate "is arguably the most fundamental indicator of the stance of monetary policy," wrote economists Christina Romer and David Romer in a 2004 paper. With inflation running at 5% in October from a year earlier, according to the Federal Reserve's preferred gauge, real short-term rates are at their lowest levels in four decades and deeply negative.

How Do You Feel About Inflation? The Answer Will Help Determine Its Longevity

Supply-chain disruptions, labor shortages and climbing oil prices have pushed inflation to a 39-year-high. But attention is now focused on another variable: Do people think inflation is here for a while?

Derby's Take: Economists See Fed Penciling In Two 2022 Rate Increases at FOMC Meeting

By Michael S. Derby

Economists are factoring in a more hawkish interest rate path for the Federal Reserve and expect its officials to reveal that shift in forecasts planned for release on Wednesday.

Based on comments from a range of Fed officials, economists also expect that after the two-day Federal Open Market Committee meeting concludes the central bank will accelerate the pace of its so-called taper, or winding down, of its bond buying asset stimulus, with an eye toward completing it by around March. Read more.

U.S. Economy

U.S. Inflation Hit a 39-Year High in November

The Labor Department said Friday the consumer-price index—which measures what consumers pay for goods and services—rose 6.8% in November from the same month a year ago. That was the fastest pace since 1982 and the sixth straight month in which inflation topped 5%. The so-called core price index, which excludes the often-volatile categories of food and energy, climbed 4.9% in November from a year earlier. That was a sharper increase than October's 4.6% rise, and the highest rate since 1991.

Inflation Hits Workers Already Worn Down by Covid-19

Lately jobs abound, consumer demand is up and roadside signs tout signing bonuses as the economy improves. Yet many workers and small-business owners say they are frustrated with inflation and with the still-disruptive effects of the pandemic.

Democrats Face Inflation, Cost Concerns on $2 Trillion Spending Plan

President Biden and top Democrats rushed to counter fresh Republican criticism that the party's education, healthcare and climate-change bill is more expensive than it seems and will exacerbate inflation, concerns shared by Sen. Joe Manchin, a make-or break vote for the plan.

Why U.S. Job Gains Are So Hard to Count During Covid-19

During the Covid-19 pandemic, economists have had an especially hard time predicting the monthly U.S. job report's headline number of jobs added and the government has routinely made big revisions to its initial estimates.

U.S.-China Frictions Undercut Efforts to Settle Global Trade Disputes

In a recent sign of the frictions spilling into the World Trade Organization's dispute-settlement function, the U.S. has since 2019 blocked new appointments to its seven-judge Appellate Body that reviews trade disputes, saying it acted because the court has a history of overreach.

Key Developments Around the World

China Shifts Back to Emphasizing Economic Stability

China shifted its focus back to keeping growth stable as policies to curb debt and speculation have triggered a sharp slowdown, particularly in the property market. "Ensuring stability is the top priority for the economy next year," government leaders said in a statement.

Brazil Grapples With Old Nemesis Inflation Amid Pandemic

While the global economy is forecast to rebound more than 4% next year, including in countries in South America, more economists expect Brazil to remain stuck in recession during 2022 as it battles one of the world's highest annual inflation rates of 10.7%.

Sky-High Vaccination Rates, Zero Taxes Make Dubai a Boomtown

Even as the Omicron variant rattled markets and forced border restrictions across the world, Dubai emerged as a pandemic boomtown, and it has doubled down on an open economy that welcomes an increasingly mobile international workforce.

Iran Bets Economy Will Hold Amid Tough Stance on Nuclear Program

U.S. sanctions on Iran have battered its economy, causing unemployment to soar and its currency to plummet. Still, Iranian officials say the country's economy is resilient and would survive even if talks to revive the 2015 nuclear deal collapse.

Financial Regulation Roundup

SEC Lures Top Enforcer Who Says Tougher Punishment Is Coming

The Securities and Exchange Commission often picks its top cop from the ranks of Wall Street's best defense lawyers. Its newest one -- Gurbir Grewal -- hadn't worked on a securities case in almost six years until he took on the job in July.

Britain Increases Scrutiny of Foreign Takeovers as U.S. Deals Surge

Britain is putting foreign takeovers of its businesses under greater scrutiny, complicating a popular route to overseas expansion for U.S. companies as they spend record amounts on acquisitions in the U.K., which for decades prided itself as a champion of open markets.

Overdraft Fees Enrich Banks, and White House Wants Less of That

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency are pressing financial institutions to scale back what officials describe as an overreliance on overdraft fees, through a combination of public warnings and potential new regulation.

SEC Investigates Private-Equity Firm Backed by Wealthy Families

The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating a private-equity firm backed by several ultrarich U.S. families after receiving complaints that its owner was using funds to cover personal expenses, documents show.

Yellen Walks Tightrope to Deliver on Biden's Climate Promises

Facing pressure from congressional Democrats and a need to deliver on President Biden's campaign promises, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen is instructing financial regulators to take steps to reduce risks tied to climate change.

Research

J.P. Morgan Moves Forward Expected Timing of Fed Rate Liftoff

J.P. Morgan has revised its outlook for when it expects the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, eyeing June for an increase compared with its prior view of a liftoff next September, bank economist Michael Feroli wrote in a note to clients Friday. The bank expects quarterly rate rises after that, Mr. Feroli added. The bank also expects the Fed to follow through on recent comments by some officials and accelerate the pace of its taper of its bond buying program, ending the asset purchases in mid-March. Mr. Feroli said that any tapering announcement will be conveyed in the Fed's statement after its policy meeting this week, noting that "we expect it will reiterate the option to adjust the pace in response to changing developments."

—Michael S. Derby

Commentary

The Federal Reserve Is the Main Inflation Culprit

Inflation is a choice for which the Fed is chiefly responsible, and it becomes embedded in the price-formation process when the central bank acts belatedly or with insufficient conviction, Kevin Warsh writes, adding that to date, the Fed has acted as an enabler.

Mr. Warsh, a former member of the Federal Reserve Board, is a distinguished visiting fellow in economics at Stanford University's Hoover Institution.
